publicationStmt.p: Fascicle 16: Dickinson's variants and published versions

lg.l: 'Twas just this time, last year, I died.
I know I heard the Corn,
When I was carried by the Farms—
It had the Tassels on—
I thought how yellow it would look—
When Richard went to mill—
And then, I wanted to get out,
But something held my will.
I thought just how red—Apples wedged
The Stubble's joints between—
And carts stooping round the fields
To take the Pumpkins in—
I wondered which would miss me, least,
And when Thanksgiving, came,
If father'd multiply the plates—
To make an even Sum—
And would it blur the Christmas glee
My Stocking hand too high
For any Santa Claus to reach
The Altitude of me—
But this sort, grieved myself,
And so, I thought the other way,
And just this time, some perfect year—
Themself, should come to me—
